title: A Case of Rape
descriptions:
A Case of Rape (1974) is a harrowing television drama that follows Ellen Harrod, a young married woman whose life is shattered after she is assaulted by a charming but volatile acquaintance, Larry. Initially, Ellen tries to return to normalcy, hoping to avoid the stigma and disbelief she fears will follow. Encouraged by her husband, David, and a close friend, she eventually reports the crime, only to confront a legal system and social climate ill-equipped to support survivors.

The police investigation is perfunctory, and Ellen’s credibility is quietly questioned from the start. When the case reaches court, the defense exploits sexist assumptions and invasive scrutiny, focusing on Ellen’s behavior, clothing, and emotional state rather than the assailant’s actions. Ellen must relive the trauma repeatedly—through statements, examinations, and testimony—while enduring subtle blame from strangers and even strained support at home as David struggles with guilt, anger, and confusion.

Larry’s outward respectability contrasts starkly with his cruelty, allowing his attorney to frame the incident as a misunderstanding. The courtroom sequences become the film’s centerpiece: cross-examination turns intimate details into weapons, and procedural hurdles make justice feel distant. Despite Ellen’s courage and consistency, the verdict fails to fully validate her experience, laying bare the systemic barriers that allow perpetrators to evade accountability.

In the aftermath, Ellen confronts a second assault by the same man, underlining the consequences of institutional failure. This time, she finds a steely resolve, demanding to be heard and refusing to be shamed. The film closes not with tidy resolution but with Ellen reclaiming her voice, while indicting a culture that doubts victims and a legal process that retraumatizes them.

A Case of Rape, anchored by a compassionate, nuanced lead performance, was a landmark in 1970s television, sparking national conversation about consent, victim-blaming, and the urgent need for legal reform, and it remains a stark portrait of courage in the face of disbelief.
